text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm that's right you heard me
I didn't say about I said food wishes
this is black berry crisp a food wishes
exclusive alright here we go we got some
blackberries and what we're going to do
is we're going to make the base of the
crisp which really should be called a
chew but we'll talk about that later so
I got a couple pints of blackberries
beautiful sweet you know that darker the
berry the sweeter the juice thing I
think it might be true because these
were really really nice berries I'm
going to put in a little bit of lemon
juice that's going to help balance the
sweetness in the dish and some sugar now
watch when I pour the sugar over see how
I sprinkle it all right I sprinkle it
over all of them now I'm gonna mix this
up so that didn't matter I could have
dumped it all in but it looked cool it
reminded me of snow so it's kind of a
little cooking meditation you do it's
relaxing unless of course no reminds you
of you know digging your car out before
work every morning then maybe just dump
it in so I'm going to mix that up and
that is so simple
that's the base of our crisp which
should be called a chew which I'll
explain later so we're going to dump
that in a lightly buttered casserole
just hold butter just wipe it in the
bottom of the pan or the baking dish and
then pour in all your berries don't miss
any of that juice that comes out and I'm
going to Pat them down I'm not going to
crush them but I want to get a nice firm
base here and the bottom of our crisp is
ready for the top we are going to make a
basic crisp crumble buckle there's about
80 names for this thing but I'm going to
go with the name crisp so we're going to
put some flour we're going to put some
brown sugar some cinnamon or 'cimmanon
as some of you say and a half teaspoon
of salt and some oatmeal some rolled
oats
some softened butter and then we're
going to take a fork and mix that up and
by the way TV chefs we know you put salt
in desserts now it's no secret so I
didn't say that this time but the salt
is a secret ingredient it really brings
out the sweetness all right so once all
that butter is incorporated you got your
traditional crisp topping you're going
to pour that over the berries and with
the tip of fork you're just going to
smooth that out so all the berries are
covered and then we're going to bake
this we're going to bake that at 375 for
45 minutes and what's going to happen
that sugar is going to caramelize and
attach itself to the oats and the flour
and that's going to form a really crispy
/ chewy top now why I said this should
be really called a chew instead of a
crisp because it's that really crispy
like potato chip crispy crunchy but
Blackberry chew doesn't sound good
sounds like something you'd get at a San
Francisco pet store so we're gonna call
it a blackberry crisp
unbelievably delicious all right do not
serve this hot see how it kind of shrunk
down the sides there'll be significant
shrinkage with this so if you serve it
hot it's just too loose it's too liquidy
all right if you let it cool down and
you get that nice shrinkage as it
settles it gets a lot thicker it gets
nice and chewy you got to give this a
try if you don't serve this with vanilla
ice cream you're crazy anyway go to the
site get the ingredients if you need
them and haven't said that in a while
and as always enjoy
